text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
LES ECHOS
-- New Prime Minister Lionel Jospin calls for joint government including Greens and Communists.
-- Unemployment rate remains 12.8 percent in April despite a 0.2 percent fall to 3,081,100 jobseekers.
-- Carmaker Peugeot unveils restructuring plan involving some 2,800 job cuts.
LA TRIBUNE

-- Prime Minister Lionel Jospin to form government this week, communist party leaders call for a shift to a 35-hour work week and an eight percent rise in the minimum wage as a condition to their taking part in the government.
-- France Telecom, GAN -CIC, Thomson-CSF and Credit Lyonnais wait for the new government's stance on their planned privatisation.
-- New car registrations fell 23 percent in May versus May 1996, with French brands suffering most.
-- Danone sells Spanish subsidiary Starlux to CPC.
-- Bouygues Telecom mobile phone operator chairman Patrick Leleu says in an interview the company aims for two million subscribers in the year 2000, a 20 percent market share.
L'AGEFI
-- Financial markets greet Socialist election victory with caution.
-- Dresdner Bank does not rule out tightening co-operation with BNP.
LE FIGARO-ECONOMIE

-- Sommer-Allibert chairman Marc Assa explains in an interview why Sommer Allibert is allying with Germany's Tarkett, says plans to regroup automobile supply activities in a German subsidiary, with a 500-million-franc share issue.
-- French EDF utility to invest in joint-venture to build and operate coal-powered electricity plants in China.
LIBERATION (Economic section)
-- Left victory in the parliamentary election to delay planned merger between Dassault and Aerospatiale, since Dassault chairman Serge Dassault insisted on a privatisation to follow the merger.
THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
-- France Telecom on hold on public offering until a new government is installed.
